According to the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA), the average cost of solar photovoltaic (PV) modules has dropped by about 90% over the past decade and is forecasted to decrease by an additional 15-35% by 2024. Besides, advances in thin-film solar cells will likely increase solar energy efficiency, predicted to reach a module efficiency of around 33% by 2024, a substantial improvement compared to approximately 22% in 2022.

Once we consider wind energy, both onshore and offshore installations are going to proliferate. The Global Wind Energy Council predicts that by the end of 2024, the total installed wind capacity will reach 980 GW, driven by technological innovations like floating wind turbines and digital optimization tools. Comparatively, in 2022, the global wind energy capacity stands at about 743 GW. Additionally, there will likely be heightened emphasis on wind farm repowering - extracting more power from existing sites by replacing older turbines with newer, more effective models.

Battery storage technologies will also play a crucial role. As per BloombergNEF, the global energy storage market is set to grow within a range of 400-800 GWh by 2024, up from around 150 GWh in 2022. The trend will be bolstered by several factors, namely declining lithium-ion battery costs, regulatory changes facilitating energy storage, and continued technological advancement. The prospect of solid-state batteries becoming commercially viable by 2024 could also be a game-changer, offering safer and more energy-dense solutions.

Two related trends that are integral to the renewable energy landscape in 2024 are 'prosumers' - individuals who both produce and consume renewable energy, and green hydrogen â€“ a potential renewable alternative to fossil fuels. With more households and businesses becoming prosumers, thanks to affordable residential solar panels and battery units, demand dynamics will shift, contributing to market growth. Regarding green hydrogen, as the technology matures, it could play a key role in energy storage, complementing battery technologies and potentially integrating solar- and wind-derived power into different sectors, like transportation.

Overall, the renewable energy landscape in 2024 will continue to evolve and grow. The trends highlighted in this projection serve as a testament to our increasing reliance on renewable sources to meet our global energy needs.
